description: The Court held that Indigent Defense's construction of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-3-510(A) was correct.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Lancaster
          County Bar Association, Petitioner,
        v.
        South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Respondent.
      
    
  


Original Jurisdiction

Opinion No.Â  26568 
  Heard October 9, 2008 - Filed December 8,
2008

PETITION FOR MANDAMUS AND FOR INJUNCTION
DENIED


  
    
      
        Francis
          L. Bell, Jr. and Mitchell A. Norrell, both of Lancaster, for Petitioner.
        James
          Hugh Ryan, III, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  We granted
  petitioner Lancaster County Bar Associationâ€™s (Lancaster Bar) request to hear
  this petition for mandamus and for injunction in our original jurisdiction.Â  At
  issue is whether respondentâ€™s (Indigent Defense) construction of S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 17-3-510(A) (Supp. 2007), which determines the membership of each circuitâ€™s
  Circuit Public Defender Selection Panel, is correct.Â  We find that it is, and
  deny Lancaster Barâ€™s request for relief.
FACTS
The Sixth Judicial
  Circuit is composed of three counties: Chester, Fairfield, and Lancaster, and its Circuit Public Defender Selection Panel will have five members.Â  Â§
  17-3-510(A).Â  Indigent Defense proposes to allocate the five members of the
  Sixth Judicial Circuitâ€™s Selection Panel as follows: 2 from Lancaster County, 2 from Chester County and 1 from Fairfield County.Â  The Lancaster Bar
  challenges Indigent Defenseâ€™s method of calculating the positions, contending
  that under the statutory formula the correct distribution is: 3 members from
  Lancaster and 1 each from Chester and Fairfield.
ISSUE

  
    Whether Indigent Defense has properly construed Â§ 17-3-510(A)(1)?
  

ANALYSIS
Section
  17-3-510(A) provides:

  (A)Â 
    There is created in each judicial circuit in the State a Circuit Public
    Defender Selection Panel, the membership of which is composed of, and must be
    elected by, the active, licensed attorneys who reside within the counties of
    each judicial circuit.Â  Each county in each judicial circuit must be
    represented by at least one member and the remaining members must be determined
    by equal weighting of county population based on the most recent decennial
    census and the most recent annual county appropriations to public defender
    operations according to the following formula:
  
    (1)Â 
      percentage of distribution of population plus the percentage of distribution of
      appropriations for public defender operations divided by two and rounded to the
      nearest whole number;
    (2)Â 
      the weighted values of each county multiplied by the number of remaining
      members in each Circuit Public Defender Selection Panel determines the number
      of additional members each county must have on the panel.
  
  Judicial
    circuits with three or less counties must have five members.Â  Judicial circuits
    with four counties must have seven members.Â  Judicial circuits with five
    counties must have nine members.

After assigning one seat to
  each county in the Sixth Circuit, two seats must be allocated under the
  statuteâ€™s formula.
Lancaster Bar asks
  the Court to enjoin Indigent Defense from utilizing its interpretation of the
  statutory formula in Â§ 17-3-510(A)(1) and to mandamus Indigent Defense to use
  the Lancaster Barâ€™s interpretation instead. 
The
  parties agree on the percentages to be used under the formula, and the method
  of calculation for the first two steps of the statute:

  
     
    Chester 
    Fairfield  
    Lancaster 
  
  
    Population: 
    28.7   
    19.7   
    51.6
  
  
    
      plus
    
     
     
     
  
  
    Appropriations: 
    25.2
    19.6   
    55.2
  
  
    
       equals 
    
    53.9  
    39.3 
    106.8
  
  
      
      
      
      
  
  
    divided by 2:
    26.95  
    18.65 
    53.4
  

While both parties agree to
  this point, they disagree on the meaning of the requirement of Â§ 17-3-510(A)(1)
  that following the division of the combined percentage by two, the result be
  â€œrounded to the nearest whole number.â€Â  Indigent Defense contends that this
  phrase requires that the percentages be rounded to the nearest whole number,
  thus Chester becomes 27, Fairfield 19, and Lancaster 53.Â  Lancaster Bar
contends, however, that the requirement that after the percentage for
  each county is obtained, it must be rounded to the next whole number results in
  the following: Chester 0; Fairfield 0; Lancaster 1.[1]
Although poorly
  articulated in the statute, we hold that Indigent Defenseâ€™s interpretation of
  the statute is correct.Â  If its view were not correct, then in any circuit in
  which one county has more than 50% of the combined population and funding, that
  county would automatically get all the â€œat largeâ€ members because the majority
  countyâ€™s percentage would round up to 1, and all other counties in the circuit would
  round down to 0.Â  Conversely, in any circuit where no county dominates, [2] then all counties will have percentages less than 50%, which under the
  Lancaster Barâ€™s theory must be rounded down to 0.Â  Under this interpretation,
  the â€œat largeâ€ members of the Circuit Panel could not be assigned since 0 times
  the number of â€œat largeâ€ members will always equal 0.Â  To read the statute
  other than as Indigent Defense has would be to rewrite it to read: In any
  circuit where one county has more than 50% of the population and funding, it
  receives all the â€œat largeâ€ members.Â  In any circuit where no county has at
  least 50% of the population and funding, then no â€œat largeâ€ members will be
  selected.
In construing a
  statute, this Court will reject an interpretation when such an interpretation
  leads to an absurd result that could not have been intended by the
  legislature.Â  Auto Owners Ins. Co. v. Rollison, 378 S.C. 600, 663 S.E.2d
  484 (2008).Â  Since to read the statute any way other than has Indigent Defense
  leads to an absurd result, we hold that Indigent Defense has correctly
  interpreted Â§ 17-3-510(A)(1).Â  Accordingly, we deny Lancaster Barâ€™s request for
  mandamus and injunction relief.Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION
The petition for
  mandamus and for an injunction is 
DENIED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1]That
  is, Lancaster Bar first converts the percentages to decimals, and then rounds
  the decimal to the nearest whole number.Â  Thus, .543 becomes 1 while .2695 and
  .1865 are rounded down to 0. 
[2] E.g., the Fourth and the Eighth Circuits.

        Phillip Eugene
          Turner, Petitioner,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Spartanburg County
  Â Roger L. Couch, Special Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No.Â  26569
  Submitted December 4, 2008 - Filed
December 8, 2008Â  

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        LaNelle C. DuRant, South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense,
          Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
          and Assistant Attorney General Michelle J. Parsons, all of Columbia, for
          Respondent.
      
    
  

PER
  CURIAM:Â  Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari from an
  order granting him a belated review of his direct appeal issues pursuant to White
    v. State, 263 S.C. 110, 208 S.E.2d 35 (1974).Â  We grant the petition for a
  writ of certiorari, dispense with further briefing, reverse the order of the
  post-conviction relief (PCR) judge, and remand this matter for an evidentiary
  hearing.
Following a trial, counsel is required to make certain the
  defendant is made fully aware of the right to appeal.Â  White v. State,
    supra.Â  In the absence of an intelligent waiver by the defendant, counsel
  must either initiate an appeal or comply with the procedure in Anders v.
    California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967).Â  Id.Â  However, the standard for a
  guilty plea differs.Â  Absent extraordinary circumstances, such as when there is reason to think a rational defendant would want to
  appeal (for example, because there are nonfrivolous grounds for appeal) or when
  the defendant reasonably demonstrated an interest in appealing, there is no constitutional requirement
  that a defendant be informed of the right to a direct appeal from a guilty
  plea.Â  Roe v. Flores-Ortega, 528 U.S. 470 (2000); Weathers v. State, 319 S.C. 59, 459 S.E.2d 838 (1995).Â  
Petitioner
  pled guilty to the charges against him.Â  On PCR, petitioner did not allege he asked
  counsel to file a direct appeal, he had viable issues for appeal, or there were
  other extraordinary circumstances which would require him to be advised of his
  right to a direct appeal from his guilty plea.Â  Petitionerâ€™s PCR application
  merely states counsel failed to inform him of his right to appeal and he did
  not know the law.Â  The State agreed to allow petitioner a belated review of his
  direct appeal issues and petitioner agreed to withdraw his other PCR issues.Â  There
  was no evidence at the PCR hearing that petitioner was entitled to be advised
  of his right to a direct appeal from his guilty plea and was not advised of
  that right, nor was there evidence petitioner requested counsel file an appeal.
The
  PCR judge found counsel did not advise petitioner of his right to appellate
  review and petitioner did not knowingly and voluntarily waive his right to a
  direct appeal.Â  However, there was no evidence of extraordinary circumstances
  which would require counsel to advise petitioner of his right to a direct
  appeal.Â  Without evidence of extraordinary circumstances, the PCR judge erred
  in finding petitioner was entitled to a belated appellate review of his guilty plea.Â  Roe
    v. Flores-Ortega, supra; Weathers
      v. State, supra.Â  Accordingly,
  the order of the PCR judge is reversed and this matter is remanded for an
  evidentiary hearing.Â  At this hearing, petitioner may present evidence on his
  allegation that he is entitled to belated appellate review of his guilty plea
  and any other allegations withdrawn at the original PCR hearing based on the Stateâ€™s agreement that petitioner was
  entitled to a belated review of his direct appeal issues. 
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Anthony M.
      Lounds, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26571
Submitted October 22, 2008 - Filed
  December 15, 2008Â Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Appellate
  Defender LaNelle C. DuRant, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense,
  Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Karen
  Ratigan, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	


JUSTICE WALLER: In this post-conviction relief (PCR) case, we granted certiorari
  to review the PCR courtâ€™s denial of relief to petitioner, Anthony M. Lounds.Â 
  We reverse and remand for a new trial.
FACTS
Petitioner was indicted for armed robbery and kidnapping.Â  A jury
  found petitioner not guilty of armed robbery but convicted him on the
  kidnapping charge.Â  He was sentenced to life without parole (LWOP).
At trial, Todd Garrett testified that on February 18, 2000,
  petitioner entered his warehouse in Greenville County and inquired about a
  job.Â  When Garrett replied that petitioner would have to submit an application
  at the companyâ€™s office located a few blocks away, petitioner â€œstepped a little
  bit closer and pulled a gun out of his left hand pocket, kept it to his side and
  said, give me your money.â€Â  Garrett stated he only had a couple of dollars in
  his wallet.Â  Another man who had been standing in the doorway approached, and
  helped petitioner pat Garrett down.Â  Garrett testified that petitioner asked
  where the rest of the money was, and he said he had a little bit in a bank
  account.Â  According to Garrett, petitioner and the other man pulled him up, and
  led him out of the warehouse to Garrettâ€™s truck.Â  
Garrett
  testified that once in his truck, petitioner found a knife and held it to his
  neck while the other man drove the truck.Â  After Garrett told them he did not
  have an ATM card and would have to go into the bank, Garrett then suggested
  they could go to his parentsâ€™ house to find some money there.Â  Garrett
  explained that he believed his life was in danger if he did not â€œget them
  something.â€
After parking the truck in his parentsâ€™ driveway, Garrett,
  petitioner, and the other man exited the truck.Â  Garrett advised the other man
  that the keys to the house were on the keychain left in the truck.Â  When the
  man went back to retrieve the keys, Garrett punched petitioner in the face and
  ran away.Â  He noticed that the men had gotten back into his truck and were
  coming back after him.Â  Once Garrett made it to a store, he called police and
  reported the incident. 
The
  police officer left after taking Garrettâ€™s statement.Â  Garrett testified that
  he and his father decided to â€œride through the neighborhoodsâ€ to find the
  perpetrators or his truck.Â  They located the truck and told police its
  location. The truck was impounded and a forensic investigation revealed a
  fingerprint on the rearview mirror that matched petitioner.Â  Garrett identified
  petitioner from a photo line-up and then again at trial.Â  Garrett testified he
  had never seen petitioner before the day of the incident.
Petitioner
  testified in his own defense and related a much different account.Â  According
  to petitioner, Garrett had bought crack cocaine from him on several occasions
  from 1999 to 2000, and Garrett owed petitioner about five hundred fifty dollars
  in connection with the drug deals.Â  Petitioner testified that he went to
  Garrettâ€™s place of business on February 18, 2000, and asked for his money.Â 
  Petitioner stated he did not have a gun, he did not threaten Garrett in any
  way, and he was not looking for any trouble.Â  When pressed on whether he had a
  weapon, petitioner stated that he did not need a weapon since â€œthere was [sic]
  two people.â€ 
Petitioner
  further explained that Garrett â€œvolunteered to go to his peopleâ€™s homeâ€ to get
  some money.Â  According to petitioner, it was Garrett who drove the truck, and
  when he stopped it, he â€œgot out and took off running.â€Â  Petitioner took the
  truck back to Garrettâ€™s warehouse and suggested that Garrett had moved the
  truck to the location where police found it.Â  The following colloquy then took
  place:

	
		
			Q. 
			You did not commit this crime here?
 
		
		
			A. 
			No, sir, I didnâ€™t.  If anything you can find 
			me guilty of is taking his truck.  I did that.  You know 
			what Iâ€™m saying?  I had to get back to my location.  
			Thatâ€™s how my fingerprint got on that window.
 
		
		
			Q. 
			All right.  And you donâ€™t make money by 
			robbing people?  You sell drugs?
 
		
		
			A. 
			Yes, Sir.  Got various drug charges to prove 
			it.
		
	

On
  reply, the State recalled Garrett who denied ever buying or using crack
  cocaine.
During
  deliberations, the jury returned to the courtroom with a request for a recharge
  on kidnapping.Â  A few hours later, the jury again returned with a request to
  rehear petitionerâ€™s testimony in full.Â  Ultimately, the jury reached its verdict
  of not guilty on the armed robbery charge, but guilty on the kidnapping
  charge.Â  Because of a prior conviction, the trial court sentenced petitioner to LWOP.[1]
Petitioner
  directly appealed, but the Court of Appeals dismissed the appeal. Â State v.
    Lounds, Op. No. 2003-UP-408 (S.C. Ct. App. filed June 18, 2003).
Thereafter,
  petitioner filed for PCR.Â  Petitioner raised several issues at the hearing,
  including that trial counsel was ineffective for failing to investigate and
  prepare for trial, and for making improper comments during closing argument.Â 
  The PCR court denied relief and also subsequently denied petitionerâ€™s motion to
  alter or amend the judgment.Â  
ISSUES

	1.  Did the PCR court err in failing to find counsel ineffective
  for inadequate preparation? 
	2.  Did the PCR erroneously find that counselâ€™s closing argument
  comments were not improper?


DISCUSSION
In
  order to prove counsel was ineffective, the PCR applicant must show:Â  (1)
  counselâ€™s performance was deficient; and (2) there is a reasonable probability
  that, but for counselâ€™s errors, the result of the trial would have been
  different.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984); Rhodes v. State, 349 S.C. 25, 561 S.E.2d 606 (2002).Â  A reasonable
  probability is a probability sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcome
  of the trial.Â  Id. Moreover, â€œwhen a defendantâ€™s conviction is
  challenged, â€˜the question is whether there is a reasonable probability that,
  absent the errors, the fact finder would have had a reasonable doubt respecting
  guilt.â€™â€Â  Ard v. Catoe, 372 S.C. 318, 331, 642 S.E.2d 590,
  596 (2007) (quoting Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. at 695).
In a
  PCR proceeding, the burden is on the applicant to prove the allegations in his
  application.Â  E.g., Bannister v. State, 333 S.C. 298, 509 S.E.2d
  807 (1998).Â  This Court will uphold the findings of the PCR court if there is
  any evidence of probative value to support them.Â  Cherry v. State, 300
  S.C. 115, 386 S.E.2d 624 (1989).Â  However, if no probative evidence supports
  these findings, the Court will not uphold the findings of the PCR court.Â  Jackson v. State, 355 S.C. 568, 570, 586 S.E.2d 562, 563 (2003). Furthermore,
  this Court will reverse the PCR courtâ€™s decision when it is controlled by an
  error of law. Â Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 145, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225
  (2000).
1.Â  Inadequate preparation
Petitioner
  argues that trial counsel was ineffective for failing to adequately prepare for
  petitionerâ€™s trial, especially given the fact that counsel had ample notice
  this was an LWOP case.Â  We agree.
A
  criminal defense attorney has a duty to perform a reasonable investigation.Â  Ard
    v. Catoe, 372 S.C. at 331, 642 S.E.2d at 597.Â  â€œ[W]hile the scope of a
  reasonable investigation depends upon a number of issues, at a minimum, counsel has the duty to
  interview potential witnesses and to make an independent investigation of the facts and circumstances of the case.â€Â  Id. at
  331-32, 642 S.E.2d at 597 (internal quotes and citation omitted).
Petitionerâ€™s trial took place on December 4 - 5, 2001. Â At the
  outset, trial counsel Greg Newell informed the court that petitionerâ€™s family
  was â€œsupposed to bring several witnesses with themâ€ for petitioner.Â  Counsel
  then requested a continuance because he had â€œfound out the names of
  these people just this morningâ€ and therefore had not had a
  chance to subpoena them.Â  (emphasis added).
Newell
  discussed witnesses for the defense a few other times during trial.Â  After a
  pretrial hearing, Newell advised the trial court there were two witnesses who
  would be arriving in the afternoon, but two others who were â€œnot available.â€Â Â 
  Newell offered his opinion that the unavailable witnesses would not â€œadd muchâ€
  to petitionerâ€™s case, although he informed the trial court that the witnesses
  would be able to connect Garrett with petitioner through drug dealing.Â  Later
  that afternoon, counsel requested assistance to locate a witness named Elaine
  Sara Hawkins who was in detention.Â  Hawkins, however, was unable to be located
  either that day or the following day.Â  Newell told the court that he had spoken
  to the two other witnesses, but contended they would not â€œadd that muchâ€ to the
  case.Â  As a result, petitioner was the sole defense witness.
According to the State, both petitioner and Newell had been served
  written notice of the Stateâ€™s intent to seek an LWOP sentence on May 3, 2001.Â 
  Additionally, Newell was served again with notice on October 18, 2001.Â 
  Therefore, Newell had several monthsâ€™ notice petitioner was facing a LWOP
  sentence if convicted.Â  
At the PCR hearing, petitioner testified that Newell had not done
  anything to investigate his case.Â  Significantly, petitioner stated Newell had
  met with him only once - on the morning of trial.Â  Although Newell had
  represented petitioner in a probation violation matter in August 2001,
  petitioner testified Newell never discussed the armed robbery and kidnapping
  charges at all. Â Petitioner further explained that on the morning of trial, he
  gave Newell the names of witnesses who could identify Garrett as someone with
  whom he had dealt.Â  Petitioner said Newell showed him some discovery that
  morning, but Newell did not discuss the file; he simply asked petitioner to
  look it over and if petitioner saw anything, to let him know.Â  
Petitioner
  presented two other witnesses at the PCR hearing.Â  George Lounds, petitionerâ€™s
  brother, testified that Garrett and petitioner bought and used drugs together.Â 
  George stated that Newell spoke to him before trial, and said he would get back
  to him, but George never heard back from Newell.Â  According to George, if Newell
  had called him to the stand, he would have testified about the connection
  between Garrett and petitioner.Â  Moreover, George stated he was surprised when
  he learned that petitioner had been charged with robbing and kidnapping Garrett
  because the two of them were â€œalways togetherâ€ hanging out and smoking together
  at a crack house.
Preston Lounds, petitionerâ€™s nephew, testified that he had seen
  Garrett purchase drugs and had also seen petitioner and Garrett together in
    Garrettâ€™s truck.Â  Preston further testified he was at the courthouse during
  petitionerâ€™s trial, but Newell never spoke to him.
Newell did not testify at the PCR hearing.Â  The State attempted to
  subpoena Newell for the PCR hearing, but was unable to successfully serve him.[2] 
The PCR
  court found that â€œtrial counsel adequately conferred with [petitioner],
  conducted a proper investigation, and was competent in his representation.â€Â 
  The PCR court suggested that because Newell told the trial court the witnesses
  would not â€œadd anything to the defense case,â€ it was a strategic reason to not
  call the witnesses.Â  Moreover, the PCR court found it unlikely that George and Prestonâ€™s testimony â€œwould have overcome the victimâ€™s testimony at trial.â€Â  
We
  find there is no probative evidence
  to support the PCR courtâ€™s findings on this issue.
We
  have recognized that when counsel articulates a valid reason for
  employing a certain strategy, such conduct generally will not be deemed
  ineffective assistance of counsel. Â Ingle v. State, 348 S.C. 467, 560
  S.E.2d 402 (2002); Stokes v. State, 308 S.C. 546, 419 S.E.2d 778 (1992).
  Â The validity of counselâ€™s strategy is reviewed under â€œan objective standard of reasonableness.â€ Ingle, 348
  S.C. at 470, 560 S.E.2d at 402. Â 
In
  the instant case, however, Newell
  did not articulate a strategy because he did not testify at the PCR hearing.Â 
  Although Newell did state to the trial court he believed the witnesses would
  not add much to petitionerâ€™s defense, we find this was not objectively
  reasonable given the defense theory of the case.Â  The only defense Newell
  presented to the jury was that petitioner and Garrett knew each other through
  drug dealing.Â  If witnesses other than petitioner were willing to testify to this
  fact, certainly that would have added significantly to the credibility of
  petitionerâ€™s case.Â  Thus, we find the PCR court erred in finding that Newell
  offered an objectively valid strategic reason not to call these witnesses.
Furthermore, both the trial transcript and petitionerâ€™s PCR
  testimony inescapably point to the conclusion that Newell simply had not
  adequately prepared the defense case.Â  Newell himself admitted to the trial
  court he had only learned of defense witnesses that morning, and therefore they
  had neither been interviewed nor subpoenaed.Â  Petitioner corroborated this at
  the PCR hearing when he stated Newell had only spoken to him about the case on
  the morning of trial. 
We hold the evidence clearly shows that Newell inadequately
  prepared for trial.Â  See Ard v.
    Catoe, supra (at a minimum,
  counsel has the duty to interview potential witnesses).Â  This was unreasonable in light of the
  fact that Newell had several monthsâ€™ notice that petitioner was facing LWOP if
  convicted.Â  Therefore, we find counsel deficient in this regard.Â  
As to
  the prejudice resulting from counselâ€™s deficient performance, we believe petitioner
  clearly was prejudiced by Newellâ€™s failure to subpoena and call witnesses who
  would have supported petitionerâ€™s own testimony at trial.Â  With its not-guilty
  verdict on the armed robbery charge, the jury necessarily rejected several
  aspects of Garrettâ€™s account, and accepted as true certain parts of
  petitionerâ€™s testimony.Â  Moreover, the juryâ€™s questions during deliberations
  indicate it also struggled with whether petitioner was guilty of kidnapping.Â 
  Thus, we find that if additional witnesses had confirmed petitionerâ€™s testimony,
  there is a reasonable likelihood the
  result of the trial would have been different on the kidnapping count.Â  Strickland
    v. Washington, supra.
Accordingly,
  the PCR court erred in not finding ineffective assistance of counsel on this
  issue.Â  See Jackson v. State, supra (if no
  probative evidence supports the PCR courtâ€™s findings, this Court will not
  uphold the findings of the PCR court) Pierce v. State, supra (the
  PCR courtâ€™s decision will be reversed when it is controlled by an error of
  law).
2.Â  Counselâ€™s closing
  argument comments
Petitioner also argues the PCR court erred in not finding counsel
  ineffective for certain comments made during closing argument.Â  We agree.
During closing argument, Newell essentially tried to point out the
  inconsistencies and improbabilities in Garrettâ€™s account.Â  However, he also
  offered his own characterization of petitionerâ€™s testimony, as follows:Â  

	But what it comes down to is two different storiesâ€¦ 
	The victim told a story.Â  And his story was that there was an
  armed robbery.Â  And in the course of that armed robbery he was taken to his
  parentsâ€™ home, let out, escaped, and then called the police.Â  My clientâ€™s story
  is, and he admitted, I deal drugs.Â  I admit that Iâ€™m a criminal in that
  respect, but I did not do this armed robbery.Â  I came there to collect some
  money I was owed.Â  The guy had built up an account, I mean, and it was getting
  too big.Â  And I wanted my money.Â  And I brought along a little muscle.â€¦Â  I
    brought along a little muscle with me.Â  Two against one, hey, weâ€™re going to -
    we want our money.Â  You owe us money.Â  We want our money.Â  A little bit of
    leaning, not necessarily beating him up.Â  But Iâ€™m standing there, two big
  guys, I need my money.Â  Okay.

(Emphasis added).
At the PCR hearing, petitioner testified that Newell â€œrepeatedly pounded his right
  fist into his left palm in a display of use of force to the jury.â€Â  According
  to petitioner, Newell pounded his fist as he said, â€œI brought along a little
  muscle.â€Â  Petitioner further maintained he told Newell that he did not rob or
  kidnap Garrett and had not threatened Garrett in any way; petitioner specifically
  denied he had told Newell he went with some â€œmuscle.â€Â  In addition, petitioner
  stated that Newellâ€™s comments, coupled with the fist-pounding, gave the jury
  the impression that petitioner used
  force, which is an element of kidnapping.[3]
The
  PCR court found that Newellâ€™s comments were not improper as he was â€œsimply
  presenting to the jury an alternate explanation of events that was implied from
  [petitionerâ€™s] own testimony.â€Â  
In our
  opinion, there is no probative evidence to support the PCR courtâ€™s findings on
  this issue.Â  While Newellâ€™s comments were not an outright admission of
  kidnapping, they significantly departed from petitionerâ€™s own testimony which
  was that Garrett â€œvolunteered to go to his peopleâ€™s
  homeâ€ to get some money.Â  The pounding of Newellâ€™s fist into his palm only
  served to highlight the inference that petitioner and the other man had
  threatened the use of force.Â  This form of argument did not advocate in
  petitionerâ€™s favor, but rather tended to support the Stateâ€™s theory on
  kidnapping.Â  Therefore, we hold Newellâ€™s closing argument comments were
  improper and constituted deficient performance.Â  
We further find petitioner was prejudiced by Newellâ€™s closing
  argument.Â  Both petitioner and Garrett testified that they went from the
  warehouse to Garrettâ€™s parentsâ€™ home in the truck.Â  Thus, the elements at issue
  were petitionerâ€™s intent, force, and the victimâ€™s consent. Â Petitionerâ€™s
  credibility was crucial as to these elements. Â The jury clearly struggled with
  whether petitioner was guilty of kidnapping as evidenced by its requests for a
  recharge on kidnapping and the replaying of petitionerâ€™s testimony.Â  Yet, petitionerâ€™s
  own counsel damaged the defense case because the closing argument did not
  support petitionerâ€™s account of what had happened.Â  Cf. Ingle v. State, 348 S.C. at 472, 560 S.E.2d at 403 (where
  defense counsel put up a witness who gave testimony contradictory to the
  petitionerâ€™s defense and was therefore â€œquite damagingâ€ to the defense, the
  Court found ineffective assistance of counsel).Â  In other words, we find there is a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s improper
  closing argument comments, the result of the trial would have been different.Â  Strickland
    v. Washington, supra.
CONCLUSION
The
  PCR court erred in not finding that counsel was ineffective.Â  Accordingly, we
  reverse the denial of PCR and remand for a new trial.
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.

TOAL, C.J.,
  PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Petitioner was convicted of voluntary manslaughter in
  1995.Â  He was sentenced to 15 years imprisonment, suspended on the service of
  seven years and five years probation.
[2] We note that the PCR
  hearing was held in 2004.Â  In 2002, Newell was definitely suspended for nine
  months. Â See In re Newell, 349 S.C. 40, 562 S.E.2d
  308 (2002). Newell was again suspended in 2003 for failure to comply with
  CLE requirements.Â  It appears Newell currently remains suspended from the
  practice of law.
[3]Â  The trial court charged the jury that kidnapping has
  four elements:Â  (1) intent (2) to take or carry away the victim (3) by force or
  threat of force (4) without the consent of the victim.Â  Specifically as to the element
  of force, the trial court stated that force â€œcan result from the threatened use
  of force by placing that person in fear of losing his life or suffering bodily
  harm.â€ Â

description: The issue on certiorari is whether the Court of Appeals erred in holding a probate court order denying a motion to remove is immediately appealable.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Furman Edward
      Fulmer, Jewel F. Oxner, Carolyn F. Garner, Sandra F. Metts, and Faye F.
      Cannon, Petitioners,
				v.
				Janette F.
      Cain, Respondent.
			
		
	



	
		
			
				Jewel Oxner, As
      the Personal Representative of the Estate of Mary F. Fulmer, deceased, Petitioner,
				v.
				Janette F.
      Cain, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Newberry County
Â Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr, Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 26572
Heard October 21, 2008 - Filed December
  15, 2008Â Â Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Pope
  D. Johnson, III, of Johnson & Barnette, of Columbia, Samuel M. Price, Jr.,
  of Newberry, for Petitioner.Â  
				Adele
  Jeffords Pope, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™
  opinion in Fulmer v. Cain, Op. No. 2006-UP-256-256 (S.C. Ct. App. filed May 19, 2006).Â  Â We reverse.Â  
FACTS
This is a dispute between siblings over the will of their mother,
  Mary Fulmer, who died on April 29, 2002.Â  The petitioners are Jewel Oxner, one
  of Mary Fulmerâ€™s children and the Personal Representative of Maryâ€™s estate, and
  four of Jewelâ€™s five siblings.Â  Respondent is Janette Cain, the remaining
  sibling.Â  In her 1998 will, Mary bequeathed 10.59 acres of property to Cain;
  Fulmerâ€™s remaining real estate was to be divided equally among the remaining
  siblings.Â  By a 2002 addendum/codicil, Mary bequeathed her house and pecan
  trees to Cain.Â  
In December 2002, after Maryâ€™s death, Jewel Oxner, as Personal
  Representative of the estate, brought an action in probate court to set aside
  the transfer of funds in certain bank accounts which were jointly held by Mary
  and Cain; Oxner also alleged fraud and sought to have the codicil set aside.Â 
  Cain counterclaimed for Oxnerâ€™s removal as personal representative, and sought
  damages for waste, and the issuance of deeds of distribution.Â  
In February 2003, Oxner and her remaining siblings filed a petition
  for formal testacy in probate court, challenging the validity of the codicil,
  and listing Cain as defendant.Â  Attached to the Petition, the siblings filed a
  complaint against Cain, reiterating the allegations of Oxnerâ€™s earlier
  complaint, seeking to set aside the codicil and alleging fraud.Â  The complaint
  also alleged causes of action for tortious interference with a contract and
  tortious interference with inheritance rights.Â  The siblings requested
  consolidation with the action previously filed by Oxner.Â  Cain moved to remove
  the siblingsâ€™ action to circuit court; she also moved to dismiss the siblingsâ€™
  action on the ground that another formal testacy matter related to the same
  subject matter was pending between the parties.Â  
The probate court denied Cainâ€™s motions to remove and to dismiss,
  finding Cain had waived her right to remove the siblingsâ€™ action by failing to
  remove the action instituted by Oxner as personal representative; the probate
  court granted the siblingsâ€™ motion to consolidate.Â  
Cain appealed, and the circuit court affirmed, without prejudice
  to Cainâ€™s right to remove the consolidated action after the personal
  representative filed an amended pleading in the probate court.Â  In an
  unpublished opinion, the Court of Appeals held the order, although
  interlocutory, was immediately appealable inasmuch as it denied Cain a mode of
  trial to which she was entitled.Â  
ISSUE
Did the Court of Appeals err in ruling the order denying Cainâ€™s
  motion to remove was immediately appealable?
DISCUSSION
Appeal may be taken, as provided by law, from any final judgment,
  appealable order or decision.Â  Rule 201, SCACR.Â  Accord Culbertson v.
    Clemens, 322 S.C. 20, 471 S.E.2d 163 (1996) (general rule that only final
  orders are appealable).Â  Appeals from the probate court are governed by S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-308 (Supp. 2007), which provides, in pertinent part:

	Except as provided in subsection (g),[1] appeals from the probate court must
  be to the circuit court and are governed by the following rules: 
	(a) A person interested in a final order, sentence, or decree
  of a probate court and considering himself injured by it may appeal to the
  circuit court in the same county.Â  

Emphasis supplied.Â  The order denying Cainâ€™s motion to remove is
  not a final order, and is therefore not reviewable under S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  62-1-308.Â  
The
  Court of Appeals found that, although the order on appeal was interlocutory, it
  was nonetheless immediately appealable because it denied Cain a mode of trial
  to which she was entitled.Â  The Court of Appeals relied upon its opinion in Truluck
    v. Snyder, 362 S.C. 108, 606 S.E.2d 792 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Truluck was wrongly decided.Â  There, the Court of Appeals held the probate courtâ€™s
  order denying the plaintiffâ€™s motion to remove a matter to circuit court was â€œa
  final order for purposes of filing an appealâ€ (under S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  62-1-308), because it impacted the mode of trial.Â  362 S.C. at 113, 606 S.E.2d
  at 794.Â  However, jury trials are available in the probate court.Â  SeeÂ 
  S.C. Code Â§ 62-1-306.Â  Contrary to the Court of Appealsâ€™ holding in Truluck,
  the order denying the plaintiffâ€™s motion to remove was not a final, appealable
  order.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The cases of this Court permitting an appeal from the denial of
  the mode of trial to which a party is entitled are distinguishable.Â Â  Salmonsen
    v. CGD, Inc., 377 S.C. 442, 661 S.E.2d 81 (2008); Flagstar Corp. v.
      Royal Surplus Lines, 341 S.C. 68, 72, 533 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2000); Hagood
        v. Somerville, 362 S.C. 191, 607 S.E.2d 707 (2005); Creed v. Stokes,
  285 S.C. 542, 331 S.E.2d 351 (1985).Â  As Justice Pleicones noted in his dissent
  in Salmonsen, â€œthe â€˜mode of trialâ€™ exception to the general rule that
  only final orders are appealable is confined to orders which abridge a partyâ€™s
  constitutional right to trial by jury.â€Â  377 S.C. at 461, 661 S.E.2d at 91.Â 
  Here, there has been no abridgment of Cainâ€™s right to a jury trial.Â  Â Â 
The Court of Appeals erred in holding the order denying Cainâ€™s
  motion to remove was immediately appealable because it is not a final order, as
  required by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-308.Â  Cf. Woodward v. Westvaco, 319
  S.C. 240, 460 S.E.2d 392 (1995) (order denying a motion to dismiss for lack of
  subject matter jurisdiction does not finally determine anything and is not
  immediately appealable); Breland v. Love Chevrolet, 339 S.C. 89, 559
  S.E.2d 11 (2000) (order denying a motion to change venue is not immediately
  appealable); Ballenger v. Bowen, 313 S.C. 476, 477-78, 443 S.E.2d 379,
  380 (1994) (order denying a motion for summary judgment is not appealable).Â 
  Accordingly, we reverse and remand to the probate court.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
PLEICONES,
  BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J., concurring in a separate
  opinion.
Chief
  Justice Toal:Â Â Â Â  I agree with the
  majorityâ€™s holding that this interlocutory order was not immediately
  appealable.Â  I write separately, however, to express my view that the probate
  court properly consolidated the two cases.Â  Both matters involve the estate of
  Mary Fulmer, similar questions of law and fact exist, and consolidation of the
  actions will promote judicial economy and reduce the risk of inconsistent
  rulings.Â Â  Furthermore, it is my view that considering the nature of this
  consolidated action, Respondent has an absolute right to remove this case to
  circuit court following the personal representativeâ€™s amendment to the
  pleading.Â  Not only does the consolidated action relate to an amount in
  controversy of at least $5,000, but also it involves a formal proceeding for
  the probate of Fulmerâ€™s will.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-302(d)(1) and
  (5) (2007) (providing that any action or proceeding
  filed in the probate court and relating to formal proceedings for the probate
  of wills and actions in which a party has a right to trial by jury and which
  involve an amount in controversy of at least five thousand dollars in value
  must be removed to the circuit court).Â  


[1]Â  Section 62-1-308(g) allows the parties, under
  certain conditions, to consent to a direct appeal to this Court.Â  They did not
  do so in the present case.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Luke A.
      Williams III, Petitioner,
				v.
				Jon Ozmint,
      Commissioner, South Carolina Department of Corrections, Respondent.
			
		
	


ORIGINAL JURISDICTION

Opinion No.Â  26573
Heard October 22, 2008 - Filed December
  22, 2008Â  
WRIT DENIED


	
		
			
				David
  I. Bruck, of Lexington, Virginia, Keir M. Weyble, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: Petitioner Luke A. Williams was convicted of murder and sentenced
  to death.Â  Petitioner has exhausted his appeals and now seeks a writ
  of habeas corpus from this Court based on our decision in State v. Northcutt, 372 S.C. 207, 641 S.E.2d
  873 (2007). 
Factual/Procedural
  Background
In
  1993, a jury found Petitioner guilty of the murders of his wife and son.Â  During
  the sentencing phase, the solicitor stated
  three times that he â€œexpectedâ€ the death penalty.Â  Defense counsel did not
  object, and the jury sentenced Petitioner to death.Â  
Petitionerâ€™s
  convictions and sentences were affirmed on direct appeal.Â  State v. Williams,
  321 S.C. 327, 468 S.E.2d 626 (1996).Â  Petitioner applied for post-conviction
  relief (PCR) raising three issues.Â  The PCR court granted relief on the third
  ground.[1]Â 
  However, this Court reversed, finding lack of prejudice.Â  Williams v. State,
  363 S.C. 341, 611 S.E.2d 232 (2005).Â  The United States District Court for the
  District of South Carolina granted Petitioner a writ of habeas corpus, but the
  Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed the district courtâ€™s decision.Â  Williams
    v. Ozmint, 494 F.3d 478 (4th Cir. 2007), cert. denied, 128 S.Ct. 1445 (2008).
Petitioner now seeks issuance of a writ of
  habeas corpus based on this Courtâ€™s decision in State v. Northcutt, 372
  S.C. 207, 641 S.E.2d 873 (2007), in which this Court reversed the defendantâ€™s
  death sentence based upon the solicitorâ€™s improper statements in the sentencing
  phase. 

Law/Analysis
Petitioner
  argues that he is entitled to habeas relief because the solicitor improperly
  stated that he â€œexpectedâ€ the death penalty during his sentencing argument.Â  We
  disagree.
At
  common law, habeas relief was only available to a convicted defendant to attack
  the jurisdiction of the court imposing the sentence.Â  See Ex parte Klugh, 132 S.C. 199, 128 S.E. 882 (1925) (recognizing that habeas corpus is a collateral
  remedy and calls in question only the jurisdiction of the court whose judgment
  is challenged).Â  However, during the 1950s and 1960s, South Carolina courts
  greatly expanded the use of the writ in order to ensure that our state afforded
  prisoners a proceeding where they could assert claims regarding constitutional
  violations.Â  See Simpson v. State, 329
  S.C. 43, 44, 495 S.E.2d 429, 430 (1998)
  (recognizing that the appeals in habeas matters
  increased between 1950 and 1970 apparently in response to United States Supreme
  Court decisions relating to the exhaustion of state remedies requirement for
  federal habeas corpus relief).Â  In 1969, South Carolina adopted our version of
  the Uniform Post-Conviction Relief Act (UPCA), which drastically limited the
  availability of habeas corpus.Â  See James Blume, note, An
    Introduction to Post-Conviction Remedies, Practice and Procedure in South Carolina 45 S.C.L.Rev. 235, 263 (recognizing that following the adoption of the
  UPCA, post-conviction relief largely replaced habeas corpus relief).Â  The UPCA directed
  that post conviction relief (PCR) was to encompass the relief available under
  the common law writ of habeas corpus, the relief available under the expansion
  of the writ, and the relief available by collateral attack under any common
  law, statutory or other writ, motion, petition, proceeding, or remedy.Â  See Simpson, 329 at 44, 495 S.E.2d at 430; S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  17-27-12(b) (2007).Â  
In a PCR proceeding, a
  defendant collaterally attacks his conviction and may raise any claims of constitutional
  violations relating to his conviction.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-12(a) (2007).Â  Every applicant has the right
  to appellate review of the denial of PCR, and every applicant is entitled to
  the assistance of counsel in seeking review of the denial of PCR. Bray v. State, 366 S.C. 137, 139-40, 620 S.E.2d
  743 (2005).Â  Counsel is required to advise a PCR
  applicant of the right to appellate review of the denial of PCR and to brief
  arguable issues to safeguard the right to appeal, despite counselâ€™s belief that
  the appeal is frivolous.Â  Id.Â  Although successive PCR applications are
  disfavored, they are not prohibited.[2]Â  See Washington v. State, 324
  S.C. 232, 478 S.E.2d 833 (1996) (allowing successive PCR
  application where the defendant was denied due process due to numerous
  procedural irregularities); Aice v. State, 305
  S.C. 448, 409 S.E.2d 392 (1991) (denying a successive PCR
  application where the defendant failed to show a sufficient reason to entertain
  the successive application).Â  
Notwithstanding
  the exhaustion of appellate review, including all direct appeals and PCR, habeas
  corpus relief remains available to prisoners in South Carolina.Â  See S.C.
  Const. art. I, Â§ 18.Â  Habeas relief is seldom used and acts as an ultimate
  ensurer of fundamental constitutional rights.Â  For these reasons, a defendant
  bears a much higher burden in a habeas proceeding.Â  A writ of habeas corpus is
  reserved for the very gravest of constitutional violations â€œwhich, in the
  setting, constitute[] a denial of fundamental fairness shocking to the universal
  sense of justice.â€Â  Green v. Maynard, 349 S.C. 535, 538, 564 S.E.2d 83,
  84.Â  It is clear that â€œnot every intervening decision, nor every constitutional
  error at trial will justify the writ.â€Â  McWee v. State, 357 S.C. 403,
  406, 593 S.E.2d 456, 457 (2004) (quoting Green v. Maynard, 349 S.C. at
  538, 564 S.E.2d at 84).Â  A defendant who seeks a writ of habeas corpus based on
  an error recognized as a constitutional violation after his conviction must
  show that, in the setting, the violation denied him fundamental fairness.Â  Butler v. State, 302 S.C. 466, 468, 397 S.E.2d 87, 88 (1990).Â  It is against
  this backdrop that we must review Petitionerâ€™s case.
At the beginning of the sentencing phase, the solicitor stated that â€œweâ€™re seekinâ€™ [the death
  penalty] and we expect to get it.â€ At the beginning of his closing argument,
  the solicitor stated again â€œwe expect the death penaltyâ€ and finished his
  closing argument with â€œ. . . you can give him what he deserves.Â  What he gave
  them!Â  And we ask for it!Â  Be bold! Â Be strong!Â  Do what this case screams out
  for!Â  We ask for it!Â  We seek it!Â  We expect to get the death penalty.â€Â  
Petitioner
  argues that this Court should issue a writ of habeas corpus based on State
    v. Northcutt, in which this Court reversed the defendantâ€™s death sentence
  based in part upon the solicitorâ€™s statements that he â€œexpectedâ€ the death
  penalty in his closing argument of the sentencing phase. Â Petitioner contends
  that the solicitor injected his own authority into the juryâ€™s deliberations and
  that the implication of the solicitorâ€™s argument was that his expectation was a
  proper consideration for the jury to weigh in deciding whether to impose the
  death penalty.Â  We disagree.
In Northcutt,
  this Court held that the solicitorâ€™s interjection of â€œexpectingâ€ the death
  penalty required reversal because such comments imposed the solicitorâ€™s
  personal beliefs upon the jury.Â  372 S.C. at 223, 641 S.E.2d at 881.Â  In our
  view, Northcutt is inapposite.Â  The Court did not hold that the
  solicitorâ€™s comments regarding â€œexpectingâ€ the death penalty constituted a
  denial of fundamental fairness shocking to the universal sense of justice.Â 
  Rather, we held that the solicitorâ€™s closing argument as a whole[3] infused the sentencing proceeding with â€œpassion and prejudiceâ€ in violation of
  S.C. Code Â§16-3-25(C)(1) (2003).Â  Northcutt at 222, 641 S.E.2d at 881.Â 
  Furthermore, unlike Northcutt which was a direct appeal, this case
  reaches the Court in the posture of a claim for a writ of habeas corpus.Â  Petitioner
  therefore bears a much higher burden in challenging his conviction.
In
  this case, although the solicitor stated that he â€œexpectedâ€ the death penalty,
  the totality of his argument did not â€œminimize the jurorâ€™s own sense of
  responsibility for [Petitionerâ€™s] fate.â€Â  State v. Woomer, 277 S.C. 170,
  175, 284 S.E.2d 357, 359 (1981) (holding that solicitorâ€™s attempt to minimize
  juryâ€™s responsibility was improper).Â  Notably, the solicitor referenced the
  jurorsâ€™ promise to â€œbase [their] verdict on the testimony and the exhibits and
  the law presented,â€ and told the jury that after considering all of the
  evidence, they should give â€œthe punishment that fits the crime.â€Â  Moreover, the
  trial judge gave thorough instructions to the jury, including the statement
  that â€œyou are never required to recommend the death penalty.â€Â  Accordingly, we
  hold that Petitioner failed to show that, in the setting,[4] the solicitorâ€™s remarks 
  constituted a denial of fundamental fairness shocking to the universal sense of
  justice.[5]Â  
Petitioner
  has been afforded more than sufficient judicial review.Â  Specifically,
  Petitioner raised this issue on PCR, but was denied relief on this ground.Â  This
  Court reviewed Petitionerâ€™s direct appeal as well as his PCR proceeding.Â  The
  federal district court, the federal circuit court, and the United States
  Supreme Court have also reviewed Petitionerâ€™s case.Â  Finality
  must be realized at some point in order to achieve a semblance of effectiveness
  in dispensing justice. Aice, 305
  S.C. at 451, 409 S.E.2d at 394. Â At some juncture judicial review
  must stop, with only the very rarest of exceptions, when the system has simply
  failed a defendant and where to continue the defendantâ€™s imprisonment without
  review would amount to a gross miscarriage of justice.Â  Id.Â  This is not
  such a case.Â  We hold that Petitionerâ€™s conviction and sentence does not constitute
  denial of fundamental fairness shocking to the universal sense of justice.

Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we deny the writ of habeas corpus.
WALLER, PLEICONES and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. BEATTY, J., not
  participating. 


[1] Petitioner raised the issue of the solicitorâ€™s improper closing argument in
  this PCR application, but the PCR court denied relief on this ground.
[2] In fact, Petitionerâ€™s PCR application mentioned above was successive.Â  The PCR
  court allowed it to proceed on the merits finding that Petitioner did not
  receive adequate assistance of PCR counsel in his first application.Â  
[3] The solicitor in Northcutt, an infant homicide case, not only
  stated that he â€œexpectedâ€ the death penalty, but also declared that it would be
  â€œopen season on babiesâ€ if the jury did not return the death penalty and staged
  a funeral procession with a black shroud draped over the victimâ€™s crib.Â  
[4] We reject Petitionerâ€™s argument that â€œin the settingâ€ refers to all cases
  containing similar facts.Â  Rather, â€œin the settingâ€ refers specifically to the
  totality of the facts and circumstances in the defendantâ€™s case.
[5] We recognize that this Court has granted habeas relief in other cases.Â  See Tucker v. Catoe, 346 S.C. 483, 552 S.E.2d 712 (2001)
  (finding the combination of the judgeâ€™s withholding of pertinent information
  regarding the deadlocked jury, the failure to instruct the jury not to
  communicate the nature of its division in future deliberations, and the giving
  of a coercive Allen charge shocking to the universal sense of justice) and Butler, 302 S.C. 466, 397 S.E.2d 87 (holding that a mentally retarded
  defendant was entitled to habeas corpus relief where coercive comments made by
  the trial judge violated the defendantâ€™s fifth amendment right).Â  In our view,
  however, the circumstances in Tucker and Butler were extreme and,
  unlike Petitioner, the defendants in Tucker and Butler were
  denied fundamental fairness shocking to the universal sense of justice.Â
