THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				E. Ervin
      Dargan, Jr. and New River Corporation, Appellants,
				v.
				James B.
      Tankersley; Donnie S. Tankersley; First Union National Bank, Charlotte, North
      Carolina, f/k/a Southern Bank and Trust Company, as Trustee of the Posey D.
      Tankersley Estate; Marilyn Tankersley; Brett Tankersley; Shay Tankersley;
      Bonnie Lynn Bridwell, individually and as co-Personal Representative of the
      Lowell H. Tankersley Estate and as co-Trustee of the Revocable Trust
      Agreement dated November 22, 1991; Tracy Karen Tankersley, individually and
      as co-Personal Representative of the Lowell H. Tankersley Estate and as
      co-Trustee of the Revocable Trust Agreement dated November 22, 1991, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  26574
Heard October 9, 2008 - Filed December 22,
  2008Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				J. Chris Brown and Jonathan P. Whitehead, both of Babb &
  Brown, of Greenville, for Appellants.
				Cecil H. Nelson, Jr., of Nelson Law Firm, of Greenville, and Stephen
  R. H. Lewis, of Covington Patrick Hagins Stern & Lewis, of Greenville, for
  Respondents.
			
		
	


JUSTICE BEATTY: Â In this quiet title action, E. Ervin Dargan, Jr. and New River
  Corporation (Appellants) appeal from an order finding James B. Tankersley and
  the remaining parties (collectively, Respondents) were the owners of a disputed
  parcel of property and awarding them damages.Â  We reverse.
I.Â  FACTS
Appellants
  brought this quiet title action to establish their ownership of a tract of real
  property in Greenville County, South Carolina.Â  Respondents claimed an interest
  in the property and asserted counterclaims for damages.Â  The disputed parcel is
  mountainous property measuring approximately twenty-seven acres.Â  
The case was
  referred to a master-in-equity, who found (1) Appellants failed to prove
  by the preponderance of the evidence that they were the owners of the property;
  (2) Respondents did prove by the preponderance of the evidence that they
  were the owners of the disputed property; and (3) Appellants have damaged
  the property owned by Respondents by cutting trees and preparing the foundation
  for a road.Â  The master ordered Appellants to execute a quitclaim deed to the
  property in favor of Respondents and to pay Respondents $25,000 in damages.Â 
  Appellants appeal from this order.
II.Â  LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal,
  Appellants argue the master erred in finding they had not proven their
  ownership claim and that Respondents have established their entitlement to the
  property and to damages.Â  We agree.Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â 
Although
  actions to quiet title are usually in equity, â€œwhen the defendantâ€™s answer
  raises an issue of paramount title to land, such as would, if established,
  defeat [the] plaintiffâ€™s action, the issue of title is legal.â€Â  Hilton Head Plantation Prop. Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n v Donald, 375 S.C. 220, 223, 651 S.E.2d 614, 616 (Ct.
  App. 2007) (citing Mountain Lake Colony v. McJunkin, 308 S.C. 202, 204,
  417 S.E.2d 578, 579 (1992)).Â  In a case tried by a judge without a jury, the
  factual findings of the judge will not be reversed on appeal unless found to be
  without evidence that reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Id.
Appellants
  and Respondents own multiple tracts of property around the disputed
  twenty-seven-acre parcel.Â  For simplicity, the property owned by Appellants,
  which is south of the disputed parcel, shall be called the Dargan Property, and
  the area owned by Respondents, which is north of the disputed parcel, shall be
  called the Tankersley Property.Â  At issue is whether the disputed parcel, which
  is in an overlap area between the two properties, is part of the Dargan
  Property or the Tankersley Property. 
As
  noted by the master, it is undisputed that the Dargan Property, the Tankersley
  Property, and the overlap area were once owned by a common grantor, the Saluda Land and Lumber Company.Â  Saluda executed two deeds that eventually led to the
  competing claims for the twenty-seven acres.
Respondentsâ€™
  Title.Â  Respondents trace their title
  to a deed executed by Saluda to one of their predecessors-in-title, Earle Hart,
  in 1943 (the Hart Deed).Â  The Hart Deed conveyed several large tracts of land
  described as the â€œBetty Orr Tractâ€ or â€œTract 1â€ (1,517 acres plus 82 acres) and
  the â€œL. I. Jennings Tractâ€ or â€œTract 2â€ (835 acres).Â  The Hart Deed described
  the property by metes and bounds and referenced a plat prepared by surveyor
  Howard Wiswall, 1918-20 (the Wiswall Plat).Â  The Hart Deed description does not
  include the twenty-seven disputed acres.Â  The twenty-seven disputed acres are
  specifically shown on the Wiswall Plat as an overlap area lying between the L.
  I. Jennings Tract, which is to the north, and the J. N., R. M. and Harvey
  Cleveland (Dolton [T]ract),â€[1] which is to the south.Â  The Wiswall Plat includes a notation about what is
  variously referred to as the Dolton Tract or the Dalton Tract.Â  The notation is
  â€œ400 Ac.â€ - meaning 400 acres, and under that is the phrase, â€œLaps not
  included.â€Â Â Â  
In
  1951, Hart conveyed approximately 704 acres of this property to William
  Goldsmith, Jr.Â  Hart simultaneously recorded a plat entitled the â€œHart Valley
  Ranchâ€ Survey, which had been prepared in 1944, some sixteen months after the
  deed from Saluda to Hart, and it was prepared at Hartâ€™s request.Â  The Hart
  Valley Ranch Survey includes the twenty-seven-acre overlap area in the property
  owned by Hart and transferred to Goldsmith.Â  In 1952, Goldsmith conveyed the
  704 acres to some of the Respondents (James Tankersley and the now-deceased
  Lowell and Posey Tankersley) by a deed that also referenced the Hart Valley
  Ranch Survey.Â  The property owned by Respondents is what is now called the
  Tankersley Property.
Appellantsâ€™
  Title.Â  Appellants trace their title
  to a deed from Saluda to E. E. Dargan (the father of appellant E. Ervin Dargan,
  Jr.) that was signed on June 28, 1951 and recorded on April 11, 1952 (the
  Dargan Deed).Â  The Dargan Deed conveyed various interests in 85 parcels to E.
  E. Dargan, including an undivided one-half interest in â€œParcel 10â€ that now forms
  part of the Dargan Property.Â  Appellantsâ€™ remaining one-half interest in the
  Dargan Property was conveyed by various deeds recorded between 1980 and
  1995.Â Â Â Â  
Appellants contend
  their title to the disputed property comes from either of two clauses in the Dargan Deed.Â  They first assert the description of Parcel 10 conveys the
  property.Â  In the alternative, they assert the language contained after all the
  property descriptions, which they refer to as a â€œcatch-all provision,â€ conveys
  the disputed property.
Parcel
  10 Description.Â  Appellants first
  rely upon the description of Parcel 10 in the Dargan Deed, which provides for
  conveyance of the following property from Saluda to E. E. Dargan:

	An undivided one-half interest in and to that certain
  tract of land in Cleveland Township, Greenville County, State of South
  Carolina, containing 400 acres, more or less, situate and lying to the South of
  the property designated on the plat mentioned above as â€œL. I. Jennings Tractâ€,
  and fully described on said plat as â€œJ. N., R. M., and Harvey Cleveland (Dalton
  Tract) 400 acresâ€, reference to which plat is hereby craved for a complete and
  accurate description of the area, metes and bounds of said property.Â  
	There
  is expressly excluded from this tract the following:
	(a) Â 16
  acres, more or less, conveyed by the Grantor to Mark Jones, by deed dated May
  26, 1934, recorded in the said [R.M.C.] Office in Deed Book 132, at page 196.
	(b)Â 
  Right-of-way granted by the Grantor to Duke Power Co., by deed dated May 27,
  1937, recorded in the said R.M.C. Office in Deed Book 199, at page 121.
	The
  tract above conveyed contains approximately 384 acres.Â  

Appellants assert
  the master should have found the Parcel 10 legal description in the Dargan Deed
  conveyed the disputed area to them because it indicated the property being
  conveyed was the tract of land lying to the south of the L. I. Jennings Tract
  as shown on the Wiswall Plat, and the tract of land to the south is the Dalton
  Tract.Â  Additionally, since Parcel 10 refers to the Wiswall Plat, the plat is
  part of the deed.Â  Appellants assert that an ambiguity arises as to whether the
  overlap area shown on the Wiswall Plat is included in the Dalton Tract, which
  is the parcel of land lying to the south of the L. I. Jennings Tract referred to
  in the Parcel 10 description in the Dargan Deed.Â  Appellants argue that due to
  the ambiguity, the master should have considered the surrounding circumstances
  and found the overlap property was conveyed in the Parcel 10 description of the
  Dargan Deed.Â  They note the metes and bounds description of the property in the
  deed from Saluda to Hart, Respondentsâ€™ predecessor-in-title, excluded the
  overlap area; thus, it fell within the parameters of what was conveyed to them
  in Parcel 10.Â  
In
  rejecting Appellantsâ€™ claim that the Parcel 10 legal description in the Dargan
  Deed conveyed the overlap area to Appellants, the master made the following
  findings:Â  (1) the disputed property is shown on the Wiswall Plat as an
  overlap in the southern portion of what is now the Tankersley Property and on
  the northern portion of what is now the Dargan Property, (2) the Wiswall Plat
  specifically states on its face that â€œlapsâ€ are not included in what was called
  the Dalton Tract and is now the Dargan Property, (3) a calculation of acreage
  based on the calls, metes, and bounds shown on the Wiswall Plat confirms that
  the overlap area is not part of the Dargan Property, (4) the Hart Valley Ranch
  Survey includes the overlap property in the Tankersley Property, (5) the
  overlap area is not included in a metes and bounds description in the 1943 deed
  from Saluda to Hart in Respondentsâ€™ chain of title, (6) the property is
  included by reference to the Hart Valley Ranch Survey in the 1951 deed from
  Hart to Respondentsâ€™ predecessor-in-title, and (7) the property is not included
  in the Dargan Deed in the Parcel 10 description because the description craves
  reference to the Wiswall Plat, which the master noted he had already determined
  did not include the overlap area as part of the Dalton Tract that had become
  the Dargan Property.Â Â Â  
We agree
  with the masterâ€™s conclusion that the Parcel 10 description in the Dargan Deed
  did not convey the overlap property to Appellants.Â  Although the Dargan Deed
  describes the property as being south of the L. I. Jennings Tract, it further
  identifies it as being the 400 acres shown on the Wiswall Plat as the Dalton
  Tract, and the Wiswall Plat expressly indicates the Dalton Tract is 400 acres
  with â€œ[l]aps not included.â€Â  
As
  noted by the master, Appellantsâ€™ own witness, surveyor Ray Dunn, acknowledged
  during cross-examination that the overlap area is not included on the Wiswall
  Plat as being part of what is now the Dargan Property because it is designated
  on the Wiswall Plat as a â€œlapâ€ and is specifically excluded from the acreage
  description.Â Â Â  
An
  expert witness for Respondents, surveyor Dick Williams, testified that he found
  the Wiswall Plat to be very reliable, and he calculated the acreage of the
  Dargan Property from the calls, metes, and bounds shown on the Wiswall Plat for
  the Dalton Property and determined that Wiswallâ€™s calculation of 400 acres does
  not include the disputed overlap property.Â  He stated the Wiswall Plat itself
  notes that the Dalton Tract consists of 400 acres and indicates â€œLaps not
  included,â€ which he said â€œmeans that any laps are not included in that 400
  acres.â€Â  
Based
  on the foregoing, the Parcel 10 description did not convey the overlap property
  to Appellants.Â  It is not necessary to rely upon the additional grounds
  enumerated by the master to reach this conclusion.Â  
Catch-All
  Provision.Â  Appellants next assert
  the master erred in finding the catch-all provision in the Dargan Deed did not
  provide an alternative basis for finding they owned the twenty-seven acres in
  dispute.Â  We agree.
The
  Dargan Deed enumerates and describes 85 separate parcels, after which there is
  the following provision wherein Saluda states it is conveying to E. E. Dargan
  all other real estate that Saluda owned in Greenville County and Pickens County:

	TOGETHER with any and all other real estate owned
  directly by the Grantor in Greenville and Pickens Counties, State of South
  Carolina, together with all easements, rights-of-way, reversions or other
  rights of any kind, as the Grantor may own directly in connection with any of
  the above described real estate, it being the intent of the Grantor by this
    deed to convey to the Grantee herein named, all real estate or other rights in
    real estate owned directly by the Grantor.Â  [Emphasis added.]

The master found
  this catch-all provision was â€œso broad as to be ineffective because it offers
  no means of identifying the Property [the parcel in dispute], particularly in
  light of the fact that the Dargan Deed contains no fewer than 85 specific,
  identifiable, and fully-described parcels of property.â€Â  The master observed
  that â€œa conveyance through a deed is not like a will, and deeds must
  necessarily identify the property being conveyed.â€Â Â Â Â  
In
  their briefs, Appellants and Respondents state South Carolina courts have not
  directly ruled on the validity of catch-all provisions, although they note we
  have made a passing reference to such provisions in one case, Hamilton v.
    CCM, Inc., 274 S.C. 152, 155, 263 S.E.2d 378, 379-80 (1980) (â€œIn 1975
  Lighthouse Beach Company was dissolved and its properties were divided between
  Sea Pines and Travelers through the execution of two deeds.Â  Each of these
  deeds conveyed numerous parcels of land, although neither deed made specific
  reference to Parcel B-2.Â  It was thereafter discovered that Parcel B-2 had not
  been specifically conveyed to either Travelers or Sea Pines but that title to a
  tract of land which included Parcel B-2 had in fact passed by virtue of a
  residual or catch-all clause contained in the dissolution deed from Lighthouse
  Beach Company to Sea Pines.Â  Upon this discovery, this tract of land was
  conveyed in 1976 by Sea Pines to Travelers.Â  Travelers then conveyed the
  property, including Parcel B-2, to CCM.â€).
Respondents
  state the Court in Hamilton did not cite the language of the dissolution
  deed, but they concede that â€œit would appear that South Carolina courts will
  accept the use of a catch[-]all provision under certain circumstances.â€Â 
  Respondents argue the description here was too vague, however, to operate as a
  valid conveyance.
South
  Carolina has expressly recognized the
  validity of a catch-all provision.Â  In Sally v. Gunter, 47 S.C.L. (13
  Rich.) 72 (1860), one of the issues on appeal concerned a challenge to a deed
  that was issued from an executor to an individual.Â  The first part of the deed
  described twenty-seven tracts of land to be conveyed, then provided for the
  conveyance of all additional real estate owned in South Carolina as follows:Â 
  â€œ[T]ogether with all other lands and real estates whatsoever and wheresoever
  situated in the State of South Carolina.â€Â  Id. at 74 note (a).Â  The land
  in dispute was not included in the property that was specifically described.Â  Id.Â  
The
  appellant challenged the deed on the basis that it did not describe the land in
  dispute with legal and sufficient certainty and that the deed was, therefore,
  void for uncertainty.Â  Id. at 73.Â  The appellate court rejected this
  argument and found the description was sufficient, citing the maxim â€œid certum
  est, quod certum reddi potestâ€ - i.e., â€œthat is certain which can be made
  certain.â€Â  Id. at 76; see also Carolina Helicopter Corp. v.
    Cutter Realty Co., 139 S.E.2d 362, 366 (N.C. 1964) (defining this legal
  maxim).
The
  weight of authority holds that such catch-all provisions are sufficient to
  transfer title.Â  See W.S.R., Annotation, Sufficiency and Construction
    of Description in Deed or Mortgage as â€˜Allâ€™ of Grantorâ€™s Property, or â€˜Allâ€™ of
    his Property in Certain Locality, 55 A.L.R. 162, 163 (1928) (â€œBy the weight
  of authority, a deed or mortgage, describing the subject-matter as â€˜allâ€™ of the
  grantorâ€™s property, or â€˜allâ€™ of his property in a certain locality, is not
  defective or void for want of a sufficient description.â€ (citing, among other
  cases, Sally v. Gunter)).Â  This principle has long been recognized by
  various courts, including the Supreme Court of the United States.Â  See, e.g., Wilson v. Boyce, 92 U.S. 320, 325 (1875) (holding a deed â€œof all my
  estateâ€ or â€œof all my lands wherever situatedâ€ is sufficient to pass title).
Although
  there may be situations where a party may not be on notice of a catch-all
  provision, that does not appear to be the situation in the current appeal.Â  Notice
  is sufficient if it puts anyone in the chain of title on notice.Â  See Fuller-Ahrens
    Pâ€™ship v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 311 S.C.
  177, 181, 427 S.E.2d 920, 923 (Ct. App. 1993) (citing Carolina Land Co. v.
    Bland, 265 S.C. 98, 217 S.E.2d 16 (1975)).Â  The catch-all provision was in
  a deed recorded within the chain of title of what is now the Dargan Property,
  and the overlap area was clearly exempted from the metes and bounds description
  of what is now the Tankersley Property in Respondentsâ€™ chain of title. 
The
  master concluded Respondents had established title to the disputed parcel.Â  In
  so doing, however, the master specifically acknowledged and found that the
  disputed parcel â€œis not included in a metes and bounds description in the 1943
  deed from Saluda to Hart in [Respondentsâ€™] chain of title.â€Â  Nevertheless, the
  master found the disputed parcel â€œis included by reference to the Hart Valley
  Ranch Survey in the 1951 deed from Hart to [Respondentsâ€™] predecessor in
  title.Â  The clear inference is that Hart was conveying what he felt he owned,
  including the [disputed parcel].â€Â  The master further noted that the Hart
  Valley Ranch Survey includes the disputed parcel in the area that is now the
  Tankersley Property.Â  
The
  master correctly observed that the metes and bounds description of the L. I.
  Jennings Tract (or Tract 2) in the Hart Deed does not include the overlap area,
  as the description expressly follows a path around the overlap.Â  Based on this
  fact, the master erred in finding that, simply because Hart included the
  disputed parcel in a plat he prepared and then purported to transfer this
  property, that he (and his successors) somehow acquired legal title to the
  disputed parcel.Â  The fact that Hart included property that â€œhe felt he ownedâ€
  does not transform the legal title.Â  Although Respondents pled other grounds
  for acquiring ownership the master did not rule on them.[2]Â 
  The basis for the masterâ€™s ruling is that Respondents had legal title to the
  property from their chain of title.Â  We hold this was error as the deeds in
  this case indicate the property was conveyed in Appellantsâ€™ chain-of-title
  under the catch-all provision whereby Saluda expressly stated it was its intent
  was to distribute all of its remaining property.
III.Â  CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, we conclude Appellants have established their ownership of
  the twenty-seven-acre parcel via the catch-all provision in the deed in their
  chain of title.Â  Therefore, we reverse the masterâ€™s ruling that Respondents are
  the owners of the disputed parcel and that they are entitled to a quitclaim
  deed and damages.[3]
REVERSED.Â 
  Â 
WALLER and PLEICONES JJ., concur. KITTREDGE, J., concurring in a separate opinion in which
  TOAL, C.J., concurs.

JUSTICE KITTREDGE:Â  I concur in result and the reasoning of the
  majority concerning Respondentsâ€™ lack of ownership of the disputed tract, a
  tract of approximately thirty acres referred to as the â€œlapsâ€ or the overlap
  area.Â  I write separately because of the incongruity of a deed that excludes a
  tract of land juxtaposed to a catch-all provision.
I
  begin with the premise that the relevant inquiry is to ascertain the intent of
  the grantor, the Saluda Land and Lumber Company (Saluda).Â  Gardner v.
    Mozingo, 293 S.C. 23, 25, 358 S.E.2d 390, 391 (1987) (â€œIn construing a
  deed, the intention of the grantor must be ascertained and effectuated . . .
  .â€).Â  In the construction of deeds, we are usually confronted with a detailed
  description of the property sought to be conveyed.Â  Yet jurisprudence is fairly
  uniform to the effect that catch-all provisions are not defective for want of a
  sufficient description.Â  The majority opinion cites to W.S.R., Annotation, Sufficiency
    and Construction of Description in Deed or Mortgage as â€œAllâ€ of Grantorâ€™s
    Property, or â€œAllâ€ of his Property in Certain Locality, 55 A.L.R. 162, 163
  (1928) (â€œA deed is generally held not to be ineffective because it describes
  the property conveyed as all the real estate belonging to the grantor.â€).Â  See
    also 23 Am. Jur. 2d Deeds Â§ 49 (2002) (â€œA deed
  describing land as â€˜allâ€™ the grantorâ€™s property or â€˜allâ€™ his property in a
  certain locality is not defective or void for want of a sufficient description
  . . . .â€).
Catch-all
  provisions may even convey all of a grantorâ€™s property when the deed
  specifically describes property which does not include the property in
  question.Â  Sally v. Gunter, 47 S.C.L. (13 Rich.) 72 (1860) (holding that
  disputed land not included in the twenty-seven tracts described in deed was
  conveyed under a catch-all provision); see also Hightower v. Blakely Hard Wood
    Lumber Co., 137 S.E. 22, 23 (Ga. 1927) (holding that a deed containing
  several described tracts, followed by a conveyance of â€œalso any and all other
  lots owned by me anywhere not herein enumerated,â€ was sufficiently definite to
  convey the disputed, non-described tract).Â  The consistent theme in the cases
  giving efficacy to catch-all provisions is the recognition that the grantor
  intended to convey the disputed tract, notwithstanding the absence of a
  detailed description.
Appellantsâ€™
  ownership claim of the disputed tractâ€”the â€œlapsâ€â€”turns on the construction of
  the deed recorded on April 11, 1952 (the Dargan Deed).Â  The Dargan Deed
  conveyed eighty-five specifically described tracts, followed by a broad
  catch-all provision, including language that the property was conveyed
  â€œTOGETHER with any and all other real estate owned directly by the Grantor in
  Greenville and Pickens Counties . . . [and it is] the intent of the Grantor by
  this deed to convey to the Grantee herein named, all real estate or other
  rights in real estate owned directly by the Grantor.â€Â  As determined in the
  majority opinion, Appellants may not rely on â€œParcel 10â€ referenced in the
  Dargan Deed.Â  Parcel 10 incorporates the Wiswall Plat; the Wiswall Plat shows
  the disputed tract, but the metes and bounds description in the plat
  specifically excludes the disputed tract.Â  We are thus presented with
  the unusual situation of an exclusion of a tract juxtaposed to a catch-all
  provision.Â  Does a catch-all provision include a tract that is identified but
  excluded in the deed?Â  I answer that question withâ€”it depends.Â  More to the
  point, it depends on the intent of the grantor.
In
  this case, it is manifest that Saluda intended the catch-all to convey all of
  its interest in the property, including the disputed tract.Â  Saluda at one time
  owned thousands of acres in this area.Â  Saluda ceased its lumber business and
  began selling its property in Greenville and Pickens Counties years prior to
  the Dargan Deed.[4]Â 
  Saludaâ€™s final sale was the Dargan Deed, which went to great lengths to
  specifically describe eighty-five separate parcels.Â  The Dargan Deed concluded
  with the broad catch-all provision noted above.Â  Given the multiple deeds out
  from Saluda, the intended finality of the Dargan Deed, and the arguably
  difficult task associated with construing the Wiswall Plat, I find the grantor Saluda
  intended to convey the disputed tract to Appellantsâ€™ predecessor-in-title
  through the catch-all provision in the Dargan Deed.
Under
  the circumstances presented, the unmistakable intention of Saluda was to convey
  whatever remaining interest in real property it had in 1952.Â  It defies all
  reason to infer an intent on the part of Saluda to convey all of its property
  except this inaccessible small tract.Â  In concurring with the result of the
  majority, my analysis rests on ascertaining the intent of the grantor.
TOAL, C.J.,
  concurs.


[1]Â  The Wiswall Plat itself appears to refer to the â€œDolton [T]ract,â€ but the plat is not clear and the parties (and other documents) have also referred
  to this as the â€œDalton Tract.â€
[2]Â  Although not ruled upon by the master, Respondents pled adverse possession and the forty year

[3]Â  Based on our disposition, we need not reach
  Appellantsâ€™ remaining allegation of error regarding the exclusion of an expert

[4]  One example of a previous conveyance is the

description: In this death-penalty post-conviction relief case, we affirm the PCR judge's decision to vacate Respondent's sentence of death and grant a new sentencing hearing. In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Donney S.
          Council, a/k/a Donnie S. Council, Respondent,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Aiken County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26543
  Heard June 26, 2008 - Re-filed December
29, 2008Â  

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
REMANDED


  
    
      
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka and Assistant Attorney General Melody
          J. Brown, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.

JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  In this death penalty post-conviction
  relief (PCR) case, the Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari
  to review the PCR judgeâ€™s decision to: Â vacate Donney S. Councilâ€™s (Respondentâ€™s)
  sentence of death; grant a new hearing for the penalty phase of his capital
  murder trial; and continue indefinitely one of his PCR grounds until Respondent
  regained competence.Â  After we issued our original opinion affirming in part,
  reversing in part, and remanding for a new sentencing hearing, the State
  petitioned for rehearing.Â  We deny the petition for rehearing, withdraw our
  original opinion, and substitute it with this opinion which revises footnote
  number seven.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On the evening of October
  9, 1992, police discovered the body of seventy-two-year-old Elizabeth Gatti
  underneath a bedspread in her basement. Â She had been hogtied with a white cord
  and layers of duct tape were wrapped around her entire head. Â Her clothes had
  been ripped, and the crotch of her underwear had been cut out. Â Surrounding her
  body were various bottles of cleaning fluids which she had been forced to
  ingest. Â Mrs. Gatti had been sexually assaulted as evidenced by a gaping
  laceration extending from her vagina into the rectal area.
Respondent was arrested for the crimes on October 12, 1992. Â In
  two separate statements, Respondent admitted to being in Mrs. Gattiâ€™s house on
  the night she was killed and that he had sex with her.Â  However, he denied committing the
  murder and implicated a man named â€œFrankie J,â€ who Respondent alleged was present with him at the
  time of the crime. Â â€œFrankie Jâ€ was later identified as Frank Douglas.Â  None of
  the physical evidence found in Mrs. Gattiâ€™s house or in her car matched Douglas.Â  
Because Respondent admitted to being in Mrs. Gattiâ€™s home when the
  crime took place, trial counsel pursued the theory that Respondent did not
  murder Mrs. Gatti but was merely present at the time of the crime.Â  The jury found
  Respondent guilty of murder, administering
  poison, first-degree burglary, grand larceny of a motor vehicle, petty larceny,
  kidnapping, and two counts of first-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC).Â  
Prior to the beginning of the penalty
  phase, trial counsel moved to allow into evidence the results of Frank Douglasâ€™
  polygraph test which indicated deception.Â  Trial counsel sought to present this
  evidence to the jury in an effort to establish that Douglas was the actual
  perpetrator and Respondent was merely present at the time of the crime.[1]Â  The trial judge declined to admit
  the polygraph test.Â  
As part
  of its case, the State called several witnesses to testify regarding
  Respondentâ€™s juvenile and adult records as well as his numerous disciplinary
  problems while incarcerated for these offenses at the Department of Juvenile
  Justice (DJJ) and the Department of Corrections (DOC). Â The testimony
  established that Respondent entered the DJJ system at ten years old with his adult
  criminal activity escalating to more violent offenses which included resisting
  arrest, assault and battery with intent to kill, and armed robbery.Â  After
  outlining Respondentâ€™s prior record, the State offered testimony to establish
  the aggravating circumstances surrounding Mrs. Gattiâ€™s murder.
In
  response, trial counsel offered Respondentâ€™s mother, Betty Council, as the sole
  defense witness.Â  She told the jury that Respondent is the youngest of ten
  children.Â  She testified she took Respondent to â€œmental healthâ€ between the
  ages of seven and fourteen and that he had been teased as a child while at
  school.Â  She also showed the jury a childhood picture of Respondent.Â  Respondentâ€™s
  mother further testified that Respondent suffered third-degree burns from a
  cooking accident, and that the treating physician told her that it would â€œtake
  effectâ€ on Respondent.Â  In terms of Respondentâ€™s adulthood, Respondentâ€™s mother
  testified that he has two young sons.Â  When asked by defense counsel what she
  would do as Respondentâ€™s mother when faced with the juryâ€™s decision as to life
  without parole or death, she pleaded for the jury to impose a life sentence.Â  
The
  jury found beyond a reasonable doubt that the murder was committed in the
  commission of the following aggravating circumstances:Â  criminal sexual
  conduct; kidnapping; burglary; larceny with the use of a deadly weapon; killing
  by poison; and physical torture.Â  As a result, the jury recommended Respondent
  be sentenced to death.Â  The trial judge denied all of Respondentâ€™s post-trial
  motions and ordered Respondent to be put to death on December 6, 1996.Â  
On
  appeal, this Court affirmed Respondentâ€™s convictions and sentences.Â  State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 515 S.E.2d 508 (1999).Â  After the United States Supreme
  Court denied Respondentâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari,[2] he petitioned this Court for a stay of execution to pursue state PCR remedies.Â  
Following this Courtâ€™s grant of the stay, Respondent
  filed his initial PCR application.Â  Shortly thereafter, Respondent indicated
  that he wished to withdraw his PCR application and be executed.Â  Pursuant to
  this request, a hearing was held before the circuit court on December 8, 2000.Â 
  As a result of this hearing, the circuit court judge ordered a competency
  evaluation of Respondent.Â  Three months later, the Department of Mental Health
  found that Respondent was not competent to waive PCR or be executed because he
  suffered from schizophrenia, undifferentiated type.Â  Respondentâ€™s PCR counsel
  then moved to stay the PCR proceedings.Â  
After a hearing, a
  circuit court judge ordered the capital PCR proceedings to be stayed
  indefinitely due to Respondentâ€™s incompetence.Â  The State petitioned for and
  was granted certiorari by this Court to review the circuit courtâ€™s order.Â  This
  Court set aside the stay and ordered the PCR proceedings to continue.Â  Council
    v. Catoe, 359 S.C. 120, 597 S.E.2d 782 (2004).Â  
Following this
  Courtâ€™s decision, Respondent filed two amended applications.Â  In his final
  application, Respondent alleged he was entitled to relief based on the
  following grounds:Â  ineffective assistance of counsel during voir dire and jury
  selection; ineffective assistance of counsel during the sentencing phase for:Â 
  (i) failing to obtain a mitigation investigator or to otherwise adequately
  prepare and present powerful mitigating evidence; (ii) failing to develop a
  consistent, credible theme for a sentence of life imprisonment; (iii) failing
  to obtain the assistance of a pathologist and failing to challenge the
  testimony of the Stateâ€™s expert pathologist regarding the circumstances
  surrounding Mrs. Gattiâ€™s death; Respondent may not be executed because he is
  incompetent; ineffective assistance of counsel in investigating Respondentâ€™s
  competency to stand trial; and ineffective assistance of counsel in
  investigating Respondentâ€™s mental state at the time of the offenses.Â  
At the hearing, PCR
  counsel called Respondent as a witness.Â  Â Â However, due to his incompetence, Respondent
  was essentially unintelligible in his testimony.Â  As a second witness, PCR
  counsel called Dr. Tora Brawley, a clinical neuropsychologist who reviewed
  Respondentâ€™s records and interviewed several of his family members.Â  Based on the
  results of a battery of tests, Dr. Brawley believed there was evidence of brain
  dysfunction, particularly in the frontal lobe.Â  Dr. Brawley testified
  Respondent began having problems when he was seven years old.Â  Although
  Respondent had an I.Q. of 106 at that time, he was diagnosed with a learning
  disability and enrolled in special education classes.Â  When Respondent was
  tested again at ten years old, his I.Q. had dropped approximately twenty-three
  points.Â  In Dr. Brawleyâ€™s opinion, this significant decrease represented an
  overall decline in general cognitive functioning. 
Next, PCR counsel called Marjorie Hammock a forensic social worker
  who compiled a â€œsocial family historyâ€ for Respondent. Â Based on her investigation,
  Hammock found that several of Respondentâ€™s family members suffered from mental
  illness, were involved in criminal activity, and have â€œsignificant educational
  deficit problems.â€Â  Hammock also discovered that Respondentâ€™s father was an
  alcoholic who was extremely violent.Â  Divorce records indicated Respondentâ€™s
  mother was granted a divorce on the ground of physical cruelty.Â  After the
  father left the home, Respondentâ€™s family moved at least seven times from one
  bad neighborhood to another and lived in several homes which did not have
  running water and indoor plumbing.Â  The family members also depended on
  government assistance for their financial existence.Â  Respondentâ€™s individual
  records revealed that he:Â  failed the first, seventh, and ninth grades;
  suffered two head injuries prior to the age of ten years old; suffered a burn
  injury which occurred when he was cooking without adult supervision at age
  seven; was treated at seven or eight years old for nervousness, sleepwalking,
  and nightmares at the local mental health center; and had attempted suicide.Â  
The
  next witness called by PCR counsel was Dr. Donna Schwartz-Watts, a forensic
  psychiatrist who began evaluating Respondent in the summer of 1999.Â  At that
  time, she believed Respondent was acutely psychotic and unable to assist his
  appellate counsel due to his â€œparanoid ideationâ€ and â€œdelusions of grandeur.â€Â 
  In 2001, Dr. Schwartz-Watts conducted an additional evaluation of Respondent in
  preparation for a competency hearing. Â Dr. Schwartz-Watts diagnosed Respondent
  with â€œundifferentiated schizophrenia,â€ which she believed began in early
  adolescence or childhood.Â Â Â  
In its
  case, the State called James Whittle, Jr., Respondentâ€™s lead trial counsel.Â  In
  terms of trial preparation, Whittle testified he filed pre-trial motions
  seeking the following records:Â  DJJ records; school records; state mental
  health records, as well as Respondentâ€™s familyâ€™s DSS records; and records from
  the vocational school attended by Respondent.Â  Whittle turned the records he
  obtained over to Dr. Everett Kuglar, a forensic psychiatrist who was
  court-appointed on August 8, 1995, for his evaluation of Respondent. Â Although
  Dr. Kuglar reviewed these records, trial counsel decided not to call him as a
  witness because he believed the Stateâ€™s cross-examination would have hurt the
  case. 
In
  terms of compiling additional mitigation evidence, Whittle met with several of
  Respondentâ€™s family members.Â  However, Whittle testified they did not offer
  anything that could be used in mitigation.Â  Additionally, Whittle filed a
  motion seeking authorization and funding approval for a social history
  investigator to aid in preparing mitigation evidence.Â  After receiving all of
  the requested records through the efforts of his investigator and law partner,
  Whittle decided not to procure a social history investigator even though
  funding had been approved. 
Instead of offering social history evidence, Whittle focused on
  presenting the defense theory that Respondent did not participate in the murder
  but was merely present when Douglas committed the murder. Â Â Whittle believed
  the strongest mitigating evidence was Respondentâ€™s statement that he was not
  the perpetrator, the presence of another individualâ€™s DNA evidence at the
  scene, and Douglasâ€™ polygraph test which indicated deception.Â  Based on this
  theory, Whittle testified he wanted to be consistent throughout the guilt phase
  and the penalty phase and that â€œit was basically an all-or-nothing approach.â€Â  Because
  he believed the trial judgeâ€™s decision not to admit Douglasâ€™ polygraph results limited
  what he could do in mitigation, Whittle decided to only call Respondentâ€™s
  mother as a witness.Â  
In his deposition, Dr. Kuglar testified he was court appointed in
  August 1995, but did not meet with Respondent until September 1996 when Whittle
  scheduled the first meeting.Â  He stated the only records he received were
  Respondentâ€™s incomplete high school records and the state mental hospital
  records from 1992-93.Â  Dr. Kuglar testified that he met with Respondent for the
  specific purpose of evaluating Respondentâ€™s mental competency and criminal
  responsibility.Â  Additionally, Dr. Kuglar testified that although he met with
  several members of Respondentâ€™s family, the interviews were not â€œvery
  satisfactory of getting anything.â€Â  
The PCR judge partially denied Respondentâ€™s application for
  relief, finding trial counsel was not ineffective:Â  (1) during voir dire and
  jury selection; and (2) during sentencing for failing to develop a credible
  theme, failing to obtain an independent pathologist, and failing to investigate
  whether Respondent was mentally competent to stand trial.Â  
The PCR judge granted Respondent relief, finding trial counselâ€™s
  conduct was both deficient and prejudicial during the penalty phase of the
  trial in that he failed to adequately prepare and present evidence in
  mitigation.Â  Relying extensively on the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s opinion
  in Wiggins,[3] the judge found trial counsel was deficient in failing to obtain Respondentâ€™s
  background records prior to the beginning of trial.Â  The judge also found that
  trial counsel neglected to pursue Respondentâ€™s earlier childhood records even
  though mental health records revealed that Respondent had a significant drop in
  I.Q. between the ages of seven and ten and had been medicated to â€œsettle his
  nervesâ€ during this time period.Â  Additionally, the judge found trial counsel
  â€œunreasonably failed to expand the investigation to include obtaining records
  of [Respondentâ€™s] immediate family membersâ€ and to conduct more than just
  â€œlimitedâ€ interviews with Respondentâ€™s family. Â The PCR judge also found trial
  counselâ€™s conduct regarding Dr. Kuglar was unreasonable given trial counsel
  failed to provide him with adequate records and only asked him to examine Respondent
  with respect to the issues of competency to stand trial and his criminal
  responsibility or capacity at the time of the offenses.
The judge concluded this deficient conduct was prejudicial to Respondent,
  stating â€œ[i]f counsel had adequately investigated and presented the available
  mitigation evidence, the jury would have heard substantial evidence in
  mitigation which was presented by [Respondent] in the PCR hearing.â€Â  Ultimately,
  the PCR judge set aside Respondentâ€™s death sentence and ordered a new sentencing
  trial.
As to Respondentâ€™s remaining grounds, the judge ruled the
  allegation that Respondent should not be executed because he is incompetent was
  not ripe for consideration.Â  The judge found that even though Respondent was
  incompetent under the standards of Singleton[4] the issue would not be procedurally
  proper until execution was imminent.Â  Moreover, given his decision to set aside
  Respondentâ€™s death sentence, the judge concluded that no remedy was necessary.Â 
  Finally, the judge held the allegation that Respondent was incompetent at the
  time of the offenses and trial counsel was ineffective for failing to
  adequately investigate Respondentâ€™s mental state should be continued until such
  time as Respondent regains competence.Â  
The State petitioned for and was granted certiorari by this Court
  to consider the PCR judgeâ€™s decision to vacate Respondentâ€™s death sentence and
  to grant a continuance as to whether trial counsel was ineffective in failing
  to adequately investigate Respondentâ€™s mental state at the time of the
  offenses.
DISCUSSION
I.
The
  State argues the PCR judge erred in finding trial counsel was ineffective in
  failing to investigate and present mitigation evidence.Â  We disagree.
In a
  PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he is
  entitled to relief.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d
  514, 517 (2000).Â  In order to prove that counsel was ineffective, the PCR
  applicant must show that: (1) counselâ€™s performance was deficient; and (2)
  there is a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s errors, the result of
  the trial would have been different.Â  Id. (citing Strickland v.
    Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984)).Â  We will uphold the findings of the PCR court when there is
  any evidence of probative value to support them, and will reverse the decision
  of the PCR court when it is controlled by an error of law.Â  Suber v. State,
  371 S.C. 554, 558-59, 640 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2007).
Although
  the State admits that trial counsel did not obtain all records for Respondentâ€™s
  immediate family, it asserts trial counsel adequately investigated Respondentâ€™s
  background and was aware of his disadvantaged background, learning
  disabilities, family turmoil, his siblingsâ€™ criminal activities, his prior
  record, and his drug use.Â  In light of trial counselâ€™s investigation, the State
  avers there is no evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s ruling because trial
  counsel made an informed, strategic decision to omit certain mitigating
  evidence in an effort to present a consistent theory that Respondent was
  present but did not participate in Mrs. Gattiâ€™s murder.Â  Even if trial
  counselâ€™s conduct is found to have been deficient, the State asserts Respondent
  failed to establish that he was prejudiced.Â  
As
  will be more fully discussed, we hold the PCR judge correctly determined that
  trial counsel was ineffective in failing to adequately investigate and present
  mitigating evidence.
Initially,
  we believe the PCR judge properly relied on the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s
  decision in Wiggins v. Smith, 539 U.S. 510 (2003).Â  In Wiggins, the
  defendant was tried and convicted for capital murder before a judge.Â  After his
  conviction, the defendant elected to be sentenced by a jury.Â  Id. at
  515.Â  In a pre-sentencing motion, defendantâ€™s counsel sought to bifurcate the
  proceedings so that he could first present his theory that the defendant did
  not act as the principal in killing the victim.Â  Counsel then intended to
  present a mitigation case.Â  After this motion was denied, the sentencing
  proceeding commenced immediately.Â  Although counsel made a general reference to
  the defendantâ€™s â€œdifficult life,â€ counsel did not present any evidence of the
  defendantâ€™s life history.Â  The jury sentenced Wiggins to death.Â  On appeal, Wigginsâ€™
  convictions and sentences were affirmed.Â  Id. at 516.
Subsequently,
  Wiggins filed an application for post-conviction relief, alleging his trial
  attorneys had rendered constitutionally defective assistance by failing to
  investigate and present mitigating evidence of his dysfunctional background.Â  Id. at 516.Â  After he exhausted his state PCR remedies, Wiggins filed a petition for
  habeas corpus in federal district court.Â  The federal courtâ€™s grant of relief
  was reversed by the Fourth Circuit, which held that Wigginsâ€™ trial counsel made
  â€œa reasonable strategic decision to focus on petitionerâ€™s direct
  responsibility.â€Â  Id. at 519.Â  
The
  United States Supreme Court granted certiorari and reversed the Fourth
  Circuitâ€™s decision.Â  The Supreme Court found trial counsel was ineffective in
  failing to adequately prepare and present mitigating evidence.Â  Although trial
  counsel obtained a pre-sentencing investigation report and DSS records, which
  revealed Wigginsâ€™ tumultuous childhood and low I.Q., counsel failed to
  investigate further.Â  Counsel also chose not to retain a forensic social worker
  despite the fact that funds were made available to commission a social history
  report.Â  Id. at 524.Â  The Court found counselâ€™s decision not to expand
  their investigation beyond the retained records was unreasonable given it fell
  short of professional state standards and the American Bar Association standards
  governing capital defense work.Â  Id.Â Â  
The
  Court also determined that counselâ€™s performance prejudiced Wiggins.Â  Specifically,
  the Court found that had trial counsel further investigated they would have
  discovered the following powerful mitigating evidence:Â  Wiggins was abused by
  his alcoholic mother during the first six years of his life; he suffered
  physical and sexual abuse while in foster care; he was homeless at times; and
  suffered from diminished mental capacities.Â  Id. at 535.Â  Given the
  strength of the mitigating evidence, the Court believed there was a reasonable
  probability that the jury would have returned a different sentence had they
  been presented with this evidence. Id.Â  Not only did the Court find that
  it was unreasonable for counsel not to investigate and present this mitigating
  evidence, it also rejected counselâ€™s assertion that the omission of the evidence
  constituted a trial strategy.Â  
In
  recent decisions, this Court has adhered to the principles and analysis in Wiggins in determining whether counsel was ineffective in failing to thoroughly
  investigate potential guilt and penalty phase evidence.Â  See Ard v.
    Catoe, 372 S.C. 318, 332 n.14, 642 S.E.2d 590, 597 n.14 (2007), cert.
      denied, Ozmint v. Ard, 128 S. Ct. 370 (2007) (referencing Wiggins and affirming PCR courtâ€™s decision finding trial counsel ineffective in failing
  to further investigate gunshot residue evidence in capital murder case); Nance
    v. Ozmint, 367 S.C. 547, 557 n.8, 626 S.E.2d 878, 883 n.8 (2006), cert.
      denied, 127 S. Ct. 131 (2006) (noting the holding in Wiggins and
  concluding defense counsel in capital murder case should have, among other
  things, investigated and presented evidence of defendantâ€™s â€œadaptabilityâ€ to
  confinement and presented mitigating social history evidence outlining
  defendantâ€™s troubled childhood and mental illness); Von Dohlen v. State,
  360 S.C. 598, 606-07, 602 S.E.2d 738, 742-43 (2004), cert. denied, 544
  U.S. 943 (2005) (concluding case was sufficiently analogous to Wiggins and holding that trial counsel in capital murder case was ineffective in
  failing to adequately prepare and present evidence in the penalty phase that
  defendant suffered from severe, chronic depression at the time of the murder given
  trial counsel failed to provide expert witness with crucial medical records and
  related information which prevented witness from conveying an accurate
  diagnosis of defendantâ€™s mental condition to the jury).
Applying
  the foregoing to the facts of the instant case, we find the PCR judge correctly
  relied on Wiggins and there is evidence to support his finding that
  Respondentâ€™s trial counsel was deficient in failing to sufficiently investigate
  and present mitigating evidence.
We
  believe it was unreasonable for trial counsel not to further investigate
  Respondentâ€™s background and present even the minimal mitigating evidence that
  was obtained.Â  Initially, trial counsel was deficient in not beginning his
  investigation into Respondentâ€™s background once the State served its notice of
  intent to seek the death penalty, counsel discovered that Respondentâ€™s DNA was
  found at the scene of the crime, and counsel learned of Respondentâ€™s inculpatory
  statements to police indicating that he sexually assaulted the victim.Â  Clearly,
  counsel should have been aware that the defense accomplice theory was not that
  strong and that mitigation evidence was the only means of influencing the jury
  to recommend a life sentence.Â  Yet, despite this knowledge, trial counsel: Â only
  obtained the DJJ and state hospital records before trial; did not request
  certain background records until the day of jury selection; did not set up a
  meeting between Dr. Kuglar and Respondent until one month before trial; and
  provided Dr. Kuglar with only limited records.Â  As in Wiggins, counselâ€™s
  conduct fell below the standards set by the ABA.Â  See American Bar
    Association Guidelines for the Appointment and Performance of Counsel In Death
    Penalty Cases, 11.4.1(2)(C) (1989) (once counsel is appointed in any case
  in which the death penalty is a possible punishment, he or she should begin,
  among other things, collecting information relevant to the sentencing phase
  including, but not limited to:Â  medical history, educational history, family
  and social history, and prior adult and juvenile record).[5]
Even
  the limited information obtained should have put counsel on notice that Respondentâ€™s
  background, with additional investigation, could potentially yield powerful
  mitigating evidence.Â  See Williams v. Taylor, 529 U.S. 362, 398 (2000) (â€œMitigating evidence unrelated to dangerousness may alter the juryâ€™s
  selection of penalty, even if it does not undermine or rebut the prosecutionâ€™s
  death-eligibility case.â€); Lockett v. Ohio, 438 U.S. 586, 604 (1978)
  (stating that mitigating evidence includes â€œany aspect of a defendantâ€™s
  character or record and any of the circumstances of the offense that the
  defendant proffers as a basis for a sentence less than deathâ€); see also Gary Goodpaster, The Trial for Life:Â  Effective Assistance of Counsel in
    Death Penalty Cases, 58 N.Y.U. L. Rev. 299, 317-339 (1983) (discussing counselâ€™s
  preparation of and impact of mitigating evidence in capital cases).
However,
  not only did counsel delay in investigating Respondentâ€™s background, he failed
  to conduct an adequate investigation.Â  Significantly, he failed to provide his
  only expert witness, Dr. Kuglar, with sufficient records and only directed him
  to evaluate Respondentâ€™s competency to stand trial and criminal responsibility.Â 
  Additionally, Dr. Kuglar, at the direction of counsel, only met with Respondent
  on two occasions, the first being shortly before trial. 
Furthermore,
  even though the funding was available, trial counsel chose not to hire a social
  history investigator.Â  Instead, he relied on his law partner and private investigator
  to collect potentially relevant information.Â  However, neither of these
  individuals was qualified, in terms of social work experience, to evaluate the
  information to assess Respondentâ€™s background.Â  
Finally,
  we believe it was unreasonable for trial counsel not to obtain Respondentâ€™s
  family records.Â  First, it is inexplicable that trial counsel deemed these
  records unimportant because they did not directly involve Respondent. Â See Penry v. Lynaugh, 492 U.S. 302, 319 (1989) (stating â€œâ€˜evidence about the
  defendantâ€™s background and character is relevant because of the belief, long
  held by this society, that defendants who commit criminal acts that are
  attributable to a disadvantaged background, or to emotional and mental problems
  may be less culpable than defendants who have no such excuseâ€™â€ (quoting California
    v. Brown, 479 U.S. 538, 545 (1987)(Oâ€™Connor, J., concurring))), abrogated
      by Atkins v. Virginia, 536 U.S. 304 (2002) (holding executions of
  mentally retarded criminals constituted cruel and unusual punishments
  prohibited by the Eighth Amendment); Eddings v. Oklahoma, 455 U.S. 104,
  115 (1982) (â€œEvidence of a difficult family history and of emotional
  disturbance is typically introduced by defendants in mitigation.â€); American
    Bar Association Guidelines for the Appointment and Performance of Counsel In
    Death Penalty Cases, 11.8.3(F)(1) (1989) (in preparing for the sentencing
  phase, trial counsel should consider investigating â€œ[w]itnesses familiar with
  and evidence relating to the clientâ€™s life and development, from birth to the
  time of sentencing, who would be favorable to the clientâ€); 11.8.6(B)(5) (stating
  that trial counsel should consider presenting in mitigation:Â  â€œFamily, and
  social history . . . professional intervention (by medical personnel, social
  workers, law enforcement personnel, clergy or others) or lack thereofâ€). Â Secondly,
  even counselâ€™s brief interviews with several of Respondentâ€™s family members and
  the DJJ records should have alerted him to the fact that the family was
  dysfunctional, Respondent had been raised in a violent home environment, and
  experienced learning disabilities. Â All of these factors constituted mitigating
  evidence and warranted further investigation.Â  
Even
  if trial counselâ€™s investigation could be deemed sufficient or adequate, we
  believe trial counsel also failed to present any significant mitigating
  evidence.Â  Trial counselâ€™s mitigation presentation consisted solely of
  Respondentâ€™s motherâ€™s extremely limited testimony.
Additionally,
  we disagree with the Stateâ€™s argument that Respondent is not entitled to
  post-conviction relief given trial counsel made a strategic decision not to
